competencyText.en-us: Grade 6-8
Supplemental
Identify and explore careers in the Information Technology cluster.
Identify the pathways in the Information Technology career cluster and the careers in each pathway.
Describe the types of places that employ individuals who have careers in the Information Technology career cluster.
Describe the variety of tasks performed by individuals who have careers in the Information Technology career cluster.
List the skills, abilities, and talents needed for careers in the Information Technology career cluster.
Identify the level of training and education required for careers in the Information Technology career cluster.
Research a career in the Information Technology career cluster and present findings to the class.
Apply math, science, and reading skills in the completion of a project or activity related to the Information Technology career cluster.
Identify computer components and their functions.
Describe what defines a computer and ways a computer can be used.
Identify the internal components of a computer.
Identify and know how to connect various computer input devices and describe their uses.
Identify and know how to connect various computer output devices and describe their uses.
Identify and know how to connect various storage devices.
Identify the internal components of a computer.
Use common computer and programming terminology.
Demonstrate knowledge of different operating systems.
Compare and contrast various operating systems used in a computer and mobile devices (e.g. DOS, Windows, Mac, Linux, Android, iOS).
Describe and use conventional file naming conventions.
Be able to identify file types by extension.

Demonstrate proficiency in using gadgets, icons, and taskbars and other pre-loaded operating system programs. (e.g. calculator, text editor, clock, volume controls, adding icons and shortcuts to taskbar and shortcut menus).
Identify operating system file naming conventions.
Demonstrate proficiency with file management (e.g. folder creation, file creation, backup, copy, delete, open, save).
Demonstrate a working knowledge of standard file formats.
Explain the history and purpose of various operating systems (e.g. DOS, Windows, Mac, Linux).
Use iterative development and debugging to explore the problem domain.
Develop an awareness of microprocessors and digital computers.
Describe the evolution of the digital computer.
Explain the general architecture of a microcomputer system.
Explain the evolution of microprocessors.
Explain software hierarchy and its impact on microprocessors.
Explain the need for and use of peripherals.
Demonstrate proficiency using peripherals.
Identify the basic concepts of computer maintenance and upgrades.
Differentiate between diagnosing and troubleshooting.
Information Support and Services
Demonstrate an understanding of the information support and services career pathway.
Define and use proper terminology associated with the information support and services career pathway.
Describe some of the careers available in the information support and services career pathway.
Identify common characteristics of the careers in the information support and services career pathway.
Research the history of the information support and services career pathway and describe how the careers have evolved and impacted society.
Identify skills required to successfully enter a career in the information support and services career pathway.
Describe technologies associated in careers within the information support and services career pathway.
Demonstrate an understanding of the Open Systems Interface (OSI) model.
Describe the evolution of OSI from its inception to the present and into the future.
Explain the interrelations of the seven layers of the OSI as it relates to hardware and software.
Describe the purpose of the OSI model and each of its layers.
Explain specific functions belonging to each OSI model layer.
Understand how two network nodes communicate through the OSI model.
Discuss the structure and purpose of data packets and frames.
Describe the two types of addressing covered by the OSI model.
Network Systems
Demonstrate an understanding of the network systems career pathway.
Define and use proper terminology associated with the network systems career pathway.
Describe some of the careers available in the network systems career pathway.
Identify common characteristics of the careers in the network systems career pathway.
Research the history of the network systems career pathway and describe how the associated careers have evolved and impacted society.
Identify skills required to successfully enter a career in the network systems career pathway.
Describe technologies associated in careers within the network systems career pathway.
Demonstrate an understanding of computer networks.
Define network and give examples of networks used at home, school, and work.
Compare types of networks, including LAN, WAN, MAN, VPN, intranet, extranet, and the Internet.
Compare common network topologies, including bus, star, ring, and mesh.
Compare various network models and their advantages, including client and server, mainframe and terminal, peer-to-peer.
Compare various methods and media for network connections, including broadband, wireless, Bluetooth, cellular, satellite.
Describe the functions of various network hardware devices, including NIC, hub, switch, router, bridge, gateway, access point.
Describe the purpose of protocols, and identify the protocols commonly used in networks, including TCP/IP, DHCP, DNS, HTTP, FTP, IMAP, POP, SMTP.
Describe the purpose and function of IP addressing and distinguish between public and private IP addresses.
Describe the OSI reference model and its layers, including tracing the flow of data between two network nodes through the OSI layers.
Demonstrate proficiency using computer networks.
Define networking and describe the purpose of a network.
Describe the conceptual background of digital networks including terminology and basics.
Describe various types of networks and the advantages and disadvantages of each (e.g. peer to peer, client and server, mainframe and terminal).
Describe the use, advantages, and disadvantages of various network media (e.g. thinnet cable, coaxial, twisted pair (cat 5), fiber optics).
Describe the function of various network devices (e.g. hub, switched hub or switch, router bridge, gateway, access points).
Describe how network devices are identified (i.e., IP addressing).
Explain the protocols commonly used in a network environment.
Differentiate between public and private IP addresses.
Describe the common ports and corresponding protocols used in a network.
Describe the difference between the Internet and the intranet.
Discuss the differences between Local Area Network (LAN), Wide Area Network (WAN), Metropolitan Area Network (MAN), and Virtual Private Network (VPN).
Programming and Software Development
Develop and apply database skills.
Start and exit database software. Save a database in various formats.
Identify the parts of the database screen.
View the database window and use the Navigation Pane. Open an object in Design view or Layout view.
Create a table.
Enter records in datasheet view.
Change the column width in a datasheet. Use Hide, Unhide, Freeze and Unfreeze fields.
Add and delete fields and create relationships between tables.
Create and modify fields, for example specify text, numbers, currency, and Yes/No.
Sort and filter record (use AutoFilter, Filter by Selection, and by Form).
Create a report.
Open and close a database.
Change the view of objects in the navigation pane.
Create a database from a template.
Edit records in datasheet view.
Add and delete records in datasheet view.
Cut, copy, and paste data in datasheet view.
Change the datasheet layout.
Hide columns in a table.
Create a table in design view and create and modify fields.
Create a form. Enter and edit data in a form.
Use form layout tools to modify database design, arrangement, and format.
Create a query.
Define database and describe real-world uses.
Distinguish between databases and spreadsheets.
Identify advantages of using a database instead of spreadsheets, electronic documents, or paper.
Define Big Data and describe how it is used in advertising.
Identify the components of a database.
Distinguish between fields and records in a database.
Describe the basic data types and formats used in a database.
Distinguish between a table and a query.
Identify database keys, including primary and foreign.
Identify the types of relationships between tables in databases.
Distinguish between a query and a report.
Identify various report types.
Describe Structured Query Language (SQL) and discuss its use with databases.
Identify and compare various database applications, including Microsoft Access, MySQL, Oracle.
Create a database table that uses multiple data types.
Add, edit, and delete records from a database table.
Sort records in a database query or table.
Troubleshoot common database errors, including data type errors, query syntax errors.
Create a basic select query on one table.
Create an action query to manipulate data.
Create a query using primary and foreign keys.
Create a simple table join.
Import and export data from a database into a spreadsheet.
Create relevant reports from a database.
Create and modify fields in a datasheet.
Save a database in a different format.
Develop and apply programming skills utilizing current technology.
Give a brief history of computers.
Describe how hardware and software make up computer architecture.
Understand the binary representation of data and programs in computers.
Discuss the evolution of programming languages.
Describe the software development process.
Describe the fundamental concepts of object-oriented programming.
Discuss the importance of the selected programming language.
Describe the structure of a simple program.
Write a simple program.
Edit, compile, and run a program.
Format a program for visual effects.
Identify compile-time errors.
Demonstrate an understanding of the programming and software development career pathway.
Define and use proper terminology associated with the programming and software development career pathway.
Describe some of the careers available in the programming and software development career pathway.
Identify common characteristics of the careers in the programming and software development career pathway.
Research the history of the programming and software development career pathway and describe how the careers have evolved and impacted society.
Identify skills required to successfully enter a career in the programming and software development career pathway.
Describe technologies associated in careers within the programming and software development career pathway.
Develop an awareness of programming languages.
Explain the history of programming languages.
Explain the need for and use of compilers.
Explain how compilers work.
Identify the three types of programming design approaches (e.g., top-down, structured, object-oriented).
Compare the various types or classes of programming languages (e.g., compiled, interpretive).
Differentiate among source code, machine code, interpreters, and compilers.
Characterize the major categories of programming languages and how they are used.
Create a model flowchart for a computer program.
Describe the stages in the software development life cycle.
Explain the components of programming languages.
Examine connections between elements of mathematics and computer science including binary numbers, logic, sets, and functions.
Demonstrate an understanding of database design, structure, and operation.
Describe a relational database and its key elements.
Describe the Entity Relationship Model (ERM).
Differentiate between one-to-many, many-to-many and one-to-one relationships.
Define referential integrity and describe its importance to managing information.
Demonstrate a fundamental understanding of Structured Query Language (SQL).
List the capabilities of SQL SELECT statements.
Execute basic SQL statements.
Apply the concatenation operator to link columns to other columns, arithmetic expressions, or constant values to create a character expression.
Use the AS clause to define column aliases to rename columns in the query result.
Use SQL to display the structure of a table.
Apply SQL syntax to restrict the rows returned from a query.
Demonstrate application of the WHERE clause syntax.
Apply the proper comparison operator to return a desired result.
Demonstrate proficiency in game development.
Describe the role of games in modern society.
Identify various types of games.
Identify the steps of the design process for creating a game.
Apply the design process to solving a problem.
Analyze (deconstruct) existing games.
Identify the tools and skills needed for creating games.
Identify design criteria and constraints.
Create storyboards to model a game’s program flow and functionality.
Identify the programmer’s role in creating games.
Identify common programming languages and applications used to create computer games.
Compare sequential, iteration (loop) and selection programming structures.
Define the term algorithm and how it applies to problem solving.
Create an algorithm to solve a problem or complete a task.
Use pseudo-code to model a game program’s flow.
Define logic errors and identify them in a game program or model.
Explain the types and uses of variables in game programming.
Describe basic Boolean concepts, including logical operators, order of precedence, expressions.
Describe the use of events, event handlers and functions in game programming.
Describe the use of parameters and arguments in game programming.
Describe the use of objects, classes and instances in game programming.
Describe the use of properties and methods with objects in game programming.
Write appropriate code to create a simple game using structured programming.
Test and evaluate the game program.
Modify the game program as needed to solve a problem.
Create an animated object to be used in a game program.
Use programming code to control the behavior of an animated object in a game program.
Demonstrate proficiency in basic programming.
Define programming and discuss its role in computing.
Explain the binary representation of data and programs in computers.
Distinguish among the three types of programming languages (machine, assembly, high-level), and give examples.
Compare and contrast languages that are usually compiled (e.g., C++, Java) and interpreted (e.g., JavaScript, Python).
Describe the structure of a simple program, and explain why sequencing is important.
Write a program design document using pseudo-code that shows program flow.
Explain strategies used in problem-solving, and relate them to computer programming.
Define the term algorithm, and explain how it relates to problem-solving.
Explain the three types of programming errors (i.e., logic, syntax, runtime), and describe the forms of testing that can be used to locate and debug errors.
Solve a problem using logic by planning a strategy, designing and testing a hypothesis, and creating a set of step-by-step instructions to perform a task.
Define structured programming and discuss the advantages of this approach.
Define the three main programming control structures used in structured programming: sequential, selection (decision), and iteration (loops).
Describe iterative programming structures (e.g., while, do/while) and how they are used in programming.
Describe selection programming structures (e.g., if/then, else) and explain the logic used for if statements.
Write a simple program in pseudo-code that uses structured programming to solve a problem.
Explain the types and uses of variables in programming.
Explain basic object-oriented concepts.
Describe fundamental Boolean concepts, including Boolean algebra, operators, logic.
Create animated objects using a high-level programming environment to control their behavior.
Create a simple program that uses animated objects.
Convert a simple program from pseudo-code into a common high-level programming environment.
Troubleshoot and debug errors in code.
Create, modify, and use a database (e.g., define field formats, adding new records, manipulate data) to analyze data and propose solutions for a task or problem, individually and collaboratively.
Demonstrate proficiency using specialized computer coding software.
Use specialized computer coding software to solve problems.
Demonstrate proficiency using specialized computer software (e.g. Swift, Python).
Web and Digital Communications
Demonstrate an understanding of the web and digital communications career pathway.
Define and use proper terminology associated with the web and digital communications career pathway.
Describe some of the careers available in the web and digital communications career pathway.
Identify common characteristics of the careers in the web and digital communications career pathway.
Research the history of the web and digital communications career pathway and describe how the careers have evolved and impacted society.
Identify skills required to successfully enter a career in the web and digital communications career pathway.
Describe technologies associated in careers within the web and digital communications career pathway.
Develop and apply web design skills utilizing current technology.
Identify and describe the various components of the Internet.
Understand the difference between web browser and search engine.
Describe the difference between a client and the various types of servers, including web servers.
Follow copyright laws.
Demonstrate an understanding of file storage and the path to describe the location of a document.
Describe how XHTML has altered the structure of HTML.
Identify and describe basic HTML/ XHTML terminology.
Identify and describe basic HTML/ XHTML tags.
Identify the elements of a web page.
Produce a web page using basic HTML tags.
Include graphics in a web page.
Use the Internet to find free components for a web page.
Create an active web page.
Define principles of acceptable web design.
Understand how different web browsers interpret pages.
Understand the role of plug-ins.
Understand graphic, audio, and movie file formats and how they affect file size.
Use animated graphics, audio and video files in a web page.
Use image editing software.
Demonstrate an understanding of compressing and decompressing files.
Understand the importance of file backup.
Demonstrate proficiency using HTML commands.
Identify elements of a web page.
Define basic HTML terminology.
Analyze HTML source code developed by others.
Create web pages using basic HTML tags (e.g. links, lists, character styles, text alignment, tables).
Edit and test HTML documents for accuracy and validity.
Create a website using basic functions of a WYSIWYG or GUI editor.
Use basic functions of HTML, DHTML, and XML editors and converters.
Enhance web pages through the addition of images and graphics including animation.
Demonstrate proficiency in webpage design.
Demonstrate an understanding of acceptable webpage design.
Design a website using storyboarding techniques.
Describe and apply color theory as it applies to webpage design.
Access and digitize graphics through various resources.
Use image design software to create and edit images.
Demonstrate proficiency in publishing to the Internet.
Demonstrate proficiency using specialized web design software.
Compare and contrast various specialized web design software.
Demonstrate proficiency using various specialized web design software.
Use Web 2.0 or internet-based collaborative technology to facilitate a web development or research project.
Create and use a collaborative environment for communicating and sharing among project team members.
Create and use a social media page to share and publish project components for gauging visitor reaction and obtaining feedback.
Demonstrate proficiency in web page development.
Identify website domains, and relate a site’s domain to its purpose.
Relate basic components of a webpage to aesthetic, functional and usable design principals.
Define aesthetic design, and explain how it can affect a visitor's perception of a website’s information.
Demonstrate knowledge of color wheel concepts and effective use of color on a website.
Compare functional and usable design principles, and explain how usability can affect a website’s success.
Critique the aesthetic design, usability and accessibility of sample websites.
Define multimedia, and identify its role in webpage interactivity.
Explain the primary steps of the website planning process.
Apply the website planning process to design a basic website.
Build the site navigation scheme for a website.
Compare webpage creation using an HTML text editor to using a graphical user interface (GUI) editor.
Compare website creation using an online site builder, an offline site builder and a content management system (CMS).
Modify an existing webpage template to create an effective look and feel for a website.
Create a website using a template.
Define Hypertext Markup Language (HTML) and related terms, including tag vs. element, container vs. empty tag, block-level vs. inline element, attribute value, semantic tag.
Identify HTML elements required to create webpage structure.
Create webpages using basic HTML tags.
Use HTML to create hyperlinks to external sites.
Use HTML to insert common image file formats into webpages, and use an image as a hyperlink.
Explain Cascading Style Sheet (CSS) technology.
Apply CSS styles to an HTML page.
Create and edit animation files, and insert them into a webpage.
Create and edit video files, and insert them into a webpage.
Use Dynamic HTML (DHTML) to enhance webpage interactivity.
Create and use a wiki or similar tool for collaborating among project team members.
Create and use a social media page to share content and collaborate on projects.
Review webpage content, verify copyright restrictions, and create meta-data before publishing a site to the Internet.
Test webpages for display, functionality, and accessibility before publishing a site to the Internet.
Validate webpage code using W3C validation tools before publishing a site to the Internet.
Describe network issues relating to websites, including bandwidth, compression, streaming, web hosting.
Explain the purpose of File Transfer Protocol (FTP) in accessing information on the Internet.
Publish a website using FTP.
Describe website security methods, including secure server vs. unsecured server, SSL, SSH, and encryption.
